Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the position of Democrats by suggesting that they have "finally admitted" to wanting a repeal of the Second Amendment, when in fact it is only a position held by a few outlier politicians.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence to support the assertion that Democrats as a whole want to repeal the Second Amendment.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the position of a few state lawmakers and one candidate for U.S. Senate represents the general position of Democrats in Congress or those running for president, which is a problematic assumption.
Exist alternative explanation: There may be alternative explanations for the statements made by the few state lawmakers and one candidate, such as personal beliefs or regional differences, which are not explored in the claim.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that there is no evidence of Democrats in Congress or running for president calling to scrap the Second Amendment.
Falters at times: The claim falters by presenting a misleading impression that the position of a few outlier politicians is the general position of the entire Democratic party.
